column4: How has your portfolio compared to the market overall?

I‚Äôve set up a portfolio with just a mission to see how I perform against the market, and to see what mistakes I make and what I can do to improve on them. I‚Äôm very young with not that much capital so this isn‚Äôt a big deal to me. I just wanted to see how you guys fair against the market. I‚Äôve been doing this for around a month and am currently down around 0.5% compared to the market.

So far my annual returns are 5.87% vs the S&P500's 7.50%, so I'm under-performing by 1.63%.I was over-performing throughout the year, but my biggest position is in Facebook which dropped by 20% after the last earnings report. I'm optimistic that they will recover by the end of the year though.Plus I have more than a third of my investing money in cash. If I had invested all of it I would be slightly outperforming the market this year despite the FB crash.I've been buying some Chinese stocks and ETFs in the past few weeks given that the Yuan is weak and the stocks are in a bear market despite performing very well. I think these investments will help me outperform in the coming years.
I use m1financei started investing earlier this year. I have a pie that is purely stocks that I picked so I could measure that myself as well.Roth is up 15%Individual up 3%Traditional up 14%

Mine‚Äôs done ok. Beat it by 2% in 2016, under by 2% last year, about even this year. But I got loads of enjoyment researching stocks and learning things. Beats a passive fund for self-fulfilment any day.

In 2016 I moved $5000 into an investment, early this year I spent the return on a massive wedding with 2 beach houses for a week and then spent a month in Europe. But now I'm right back where I was in 2016.

Down compared to SPY YTD, but only by a fraction of a percentage. Personally, I'm fairly conservative and have ~15% in cash and am heavily invested in index funds and safer companies. I'm pretty happy with how it has gone so far.

My SP500 shares have been going up as expected. But one stock that is seriously in red is GE. I bought a shit ton at $22 and we all know how that played out. GE was supposed to be a 'buy and keep for 50 years' stock. It may very well rebound but it sure does suck ATM

+120% in the last year, +340% since june 2016.Yes, I do visit WSBEdit: [Evidence](https://imgur.com/a/99WLmPb)If anyone here is a hedge fund manager or a recruiter for GS I am graduating next spring and I am looking for a job :D /s
+55%.  Thank you cannabis.
Currently at 12% so not bad. Mostly AMZN and financial tech have been so kind to me this year
83.2% over the past year, not too bad
DELETED
I turned 700 into 5k, so I‚Äôm killing the market. Unfortunately I decided to go for full custody of my kids. So I‚Äôve had to give most of that to my lawyer...back to square one. üòì
401k = 19.2% yearly & 12.07% YTDTaxable account = 62% yearly & 45% YTDThose hold majority of my holdings Edit: excludes dividends

I find it quite difficult to know if I'm outperforming the market or not  aside from the bunch of dealing accounts I have. For example I have a stock portfolio several years old. Throughout each of these years I contributed more to the portfolio and each contribution weighs down on my overall profit due to the increased allocation of cash. I could compare the performance of the S&P 500 throughout these years but this would only work for those with portfolios that had an initial lump sum and didn't contribute more over time. Am I overcomplicating this? Is there a simple way? Are people just looking at the profit % and age of the dealing account and comparing the S&P 500 performance over these years? It doesn't seem that accurate to me.
13.81% annual return vs SPY's 11.34%, DRIP included.
Remember not everyone goal is to beat the market.
Up about 300% from the past 2 years of investing.
My portfolio has done roughly as well as VT has done, which is almost 70% of it.By market do we just mean the S&P500? That‚Äôs not what I benchmark my portfolio against.
Total portfolio ~ 500% or so over S&P in last 24 months. About half equities, half something that shall not be named because its a dirty word around these parts.
I'm up 28.48% on the year. Not bad but not great. Half my portfolio is index funds and half of it is individual equities. I could do better but I'm still learning.

I‚Äôm at 49.7% YTD, but my portfolio is heavily weighted in S&P Growth ETF‚Äôs and large positions in Apple/Amazon. Certainly a more risky position than some would like, but with how it‚Äôs performed I‚Äôm satisfied.
Im at just about 30% for the year. Have made some lucky trades.
Big takeaway is I see single stocks moving like crazy.. But market steadily increasing. So odd to see that FB is not the center of the universe and other stocks could care less about one company.
I was doing slightly better than the market until I got greedy and tried options. Now I'm doing half as good as the market.
My 12 month performance on my TSP is 15.32% and my Vanguard accounts combined 12-month is at 12.3% (as of Jul 31).
Am I the only one who lost money this year? I start investing and I am down 5% this year. Should have just bought sp500
Currently 14%. Got lucky with Nvidia and Netflix shares
+34% since January
I'm +18% this year (but I'll leave out it was close to zero the years before)
Underperforming in one account due to international exposure and Facebook, which was my largest holding until it plummeted. The other account is up 11% YTD but is more US centric.
Up almost 9% on the year in the Roth.401k up 13 on the year.Haven't beaten nasdaq in my entire investing career.  And won't this year either.

I‚Äôm fairly concentrated and have a somewhat low total balance but I‚Äôm up ~38% this year. Mostly thanks to some great tech stocks I bought early in the year.  I see a huge amount of volatility in this account but hope I can stomach it in not such good years.

I'm up 10% YTD and about 20% each of the last two years with a 0.8 portfolio beta.  It's mostly a dividend growth portfolio with a couple non-dividend paying positions as well.  Most of my strategy is centered around value investing.

This has been my best year investing by far. I'm up about 50%. In 2017, I was up around 30%Previous years, I had few years where I didn't beat the market. And a few I was basically the same. Part of it is luck, part is spending more time researching before buying into something than used to. The last is not taking crazy risks. No penny stocks, no options.

Beating overall, but I can't say by how much. I'm eyeballing it from the Personal Capital charts, and this understates my performance as I sell winners (rare) and buy losers (all it does is backtest your current holdings). Even in that case I've outperformed the market on this chart by almost 10% since January 2017.Of course it does help to be heavily concentrated in AAPL and V.EDIT: Equity only, long only (except for two shorts a couple years ago that were bad ideas), no leverage.

In my brokerage account, I‚Äôve hit 30% gains year to date vs the S&P‚Äôs 16% gains over the same period.  Pretty excited but I also know the mantra that you never beat the market so I‚Äôm worried if a correction comes I‚Äôll be hit hard.  Actually considering selling a bunch of positions only because I might buy a commercial building in the next year. Are there any other fidelity users? I was trying to figure out for he life of me how I could easily tell what my investments were doing vs the S&P500 and then realized it‚Äôs right on the front of the App when you log in.  It appears to only update once a month but maybe there is a place to see it in more detail on the desktop login?
My company 401k is at 19% which I'm the one making the moves with the funds they have available. My IRA is about 30% return so far this year.

I‚Äôm up 150+% up since last March when I started. Nvidia, Shopify, Nutanix, Zscaler, OKTA, Square, AYX have been some of my holdings (I sold NVDA and Shopify last month). I‚Äôm very fortunate. My name explains my strategy

Started investing in April this year and have a 8.37%YTD return. About 60% of my portfolio is in VTI and 20% in VNQ and VGT each.Im adding about $5k/month and starting with an ETF foundation while I learn. Will be adding single stocks with dividends next
27% yoy, 25% two years ago, beat the nasdaq the proceeding three (maybe two, don't remember). My portfolio was high risk! Many people wouldn't be comfortable taking my positions.

I average about 10-15% more than the market, including dividends for the past several years. Similarly to Warren Buffet, I only buy mostly financial stocks that I believe are under valued.‚ÄãSome of my best trades have been buying stocks trading below book value.Word of advice for a newcomer: Remember that your not in the business of fortune telling, your in the business of buying businesses. You want to buy companies that RIGHT NOW are under valued. If a company has a book value of 1b$ and is trading for 700 mill$, and revenues/profit are steady, you've basically bought 1$ for 70 cents. ‚ÄãI've found these opportunities are usually in mid-cap stocks trading with a few hundred million or 1-2 billion market cap, but occasionally even a large cap stock presents itself as a good opportunity.​​
I am about 9 inches, not completely hard.
I don‚Äôt really care.  I‚Äôd rather have it underperform now and outperform in a bear market.  (Although I just peeked and I outperformed ytd, which actually surprises the crap out of me.).

Almost all of my paper accounts beat the market...my real one usually matches it or comes just under it. My real account differs in that I have about 20% in high yield dividends which aren't seen as gains, and I have about 5% in speculative positions in rite aid and a weed stock...  RAD was doing ok for a while but now sits at about (30%) and TRTC is at (45%).

For me it is hard to compare. If I look at the past year and see I am up say 4% and the market is up 10% (fake numbers) this really means nothing to me. I added money to my account (on average) 3x a month. the past year has my original balance plus $ each time I add more. It is hard to compare as I have money in my account for 3 days (I bought some McDonalds this past week). If I look at my year chart it is acting as if I had that money in there since the start.
over 150% all time, safe to say I'm beating the market

I‚Äôm trying to upload an image for proof but can‚Äôt figure it out. I‚Äôm up about 90% for the last 3 years vs S&P‚Äôs about 46% gain. I own a good amount of Berkshire too, which has been dragging down my % gain. I have $603k.
I think it's more accurate to say you're underpreforming the market by 27%.
If ‚Äúifs‚Äù and ‚Äúbuts‚Äù were candy and nuts, oh what a Christmas we‚Äôd have!
You are only under performing if you are taking similar or more risk to the SP500 (if that's your benchmark)Given you are 1/3 in cash your portfolio is basically matching the SP500.​
Facebook also took a huge chunk from me, but would stay away from they Chinese market - they are falling for a reason.
Worth it
Cheers to a great year.
BTC? ETH?
Positions or ban. Just kidding, but I would really like to know how you have gotten those sweet gains
fucking lol.   this sub ...... you gambled w/ a few k and made a few more .... so basically a lucky wknd in vegas spread over 2 years of throwing darts?  nice good luck w/ the job hunt you savage
...how? Teach me master
I wish I had your idea of not too bad :(
Solid. And even if you don‚Äôt exactly beat it, it‚Äôs still more rewarding than vanguard funds.
Good job though on the investments . If you did it once, you will be able to replicate again later when you're able to again
What's your 401k allocated in?

Fool.com has a feature called Scorecards. You can input your trades and it‚Äôll compare them against the S&P 500 and give you your annual return and your annual return vs. the S&P 500. It is manual (you need to enter your trades one-by-one manually) but if you‚Äôre really curious, spend the 2-3 hours inputting the info. I used it for about 6 months before deciding I wanted to build something in my excel that I could tinker with but I didn‚Äôt stop because Scorecards didn‚Äôt work. I had no issues with it.
Use the XIRR function in Excel.  All you need to know are your beginning balance, ending balance, and the dates and amounts of any deposits or withdrawals.

I find [this article](https://www.aaii.com/journal/article/how-to-calculate-the-return-on-your-portfolio) explaining quite well what you're asking, with easy to follow example. The optimal calculation depends on your purposes and how significant your fund deposit/withdrawal are. Personally I use time-weighted return formula mentioned in that article to make a google sheet for myself since there isn't any decent portfolio tracking tools for my market.
If you're not doing a passive strategy, your goal better be to outperform the market on a risk adjusted basis.
It should be if you're doing anything other than index funds and ETFs
Exactly.
but in this market it's tough to not have some exposure at least 5-10% if you're mostly protected, and set yourself a limit to get out.
Did you use any derivatives in your portfolio?
>If a company has a book value of 1 mill$ and is trading for 700 mill$, and revenues/profit are steady, you've basically bought 1$ for 70 cents.Oh boy
You need better tools. Build them in excel
The S&P 500 is up over 12,000%.​See, without a timeframe, you aren't beating the market. You're, in fact, getting crushed by it.
1.63 pp (percentage points) is what he meant.
If I had three wheels, I‚Äôd be a tricycle.
Not true, the s&p is up over that amount this year

I got into AMD at $5, ABBV at 60, DPZ at 150, TTWO @50ish among others borrowing around 80% of my balance on margin, although without using options (except selling covered calls of AMD to pay the margin interest). Right now I am pretty heavy on China with IQ and Baidu making a decent part of my portfolio. I don't think that I am particularly skilled. I am just reckless and lucky.
I sunk myself into amazon and not much else, so im way above the market. I think the way to get those sweet gains is risk sour losses

Past results are no guarantee of future performance." Using leverage/picking high volatiliy stocks can go quickly both ways under different market conditions. But it's of course a good indication."
~50% large blend fund and ~50% large growth fund (fidelity funds)
Thanks this looks useful. It's going to take me ages to do but hopefully it gives me some good insight.

fucking lol.  u/SirGlass is actually partly rightwhat is the market" u/theAndrewWiggins?   is it SPY?  is it QQQ?  is it DIA?  is it 50% US / 50% int'l equities?  do we include debt?  is the market 90/10 stocks/bonds?  is it 70/30?do we include IJH or IJS?  how far out on the risk spectrum should we go .... does the market involve VWO? or VWOB?  what is "the market"????pro tip: STOP THINKING IN TERMS OF MARKETS (ie. top-down) AND START THINKING IN TERMS OF BUSINESSES (ie. bottom-up) AND YOU GUYS MIGHT ACTUALLY LEARN SOMETHING "

Not really. Being correlated with the market is fantastic, until 2008.If you are truly uncorrelated, beating the market during a bull market shouldn't be expected (the thing everyone forgets about hedge funds).Edit: A market neutral fund shouldn't necessarily be expected to beat the market in a bull run.

Maybe if you are young, once you get older you want risk adjusted returns.If you are 60 years old looking to retire you are looking for safer investments and probably will have more investments in bonds or safer blue chip or utility stocks

Agreed, but I‚Äôm sure he meant 1B. Generally not a bad practice, but it‚Äôs important to go a little further and really understand why the market is pricing the company below book value before reaching a consensus and buying.

If you want to make above average returns in the stock market, you have to take risk. There is simply no other way.

So when someone the market" I always just take it to mean SPY.However you are right...SPY isn't the market, there are stocks outside of the index, there are foreign stocks, small/midcap stocks ect. And that is just stock there is a hold bond market too.However when some one says "compared to the market" I just assume they are talking about SPY index."
If you don't know what the market is, I think this is the wrong sub for you.

True i guess i see your point. However, doesn't this just lead to below average returns but at a more consistent rate?Would this be a good strategy when you're closer to retirement rather than going more bonds and less equities?
This. I think it goes without saying that ofc you always need to do your proper due diligence as investor, actually read the financial statements and every note. Then proceed to make a decision.

Thats not a long time and its been a good bull market.Just saying I could go to a casino and bet it on odd and 2x money.Doesn't really mean I have a good strategy , or mean I have a consistent  way to make moneybut good job, keep up the gains and lets see if you can beat the market for the next 10 years
Cash should be a position too. So if the sp500 crashes 50% while you‚Äôre in alll cash you didn‚Äôt beat the index by 50%?
I guess I'm old fashion, I don't use ytd
He shouldn't be downvoted for telling us how he made money. I'm not even a crypto fan, but the hate has gone too far.

You could lever up, instead of taking on whatever beta you were trying to avoid, and take on risk (and the corresponding returns) that way instead.I was merely making a point that highly correlated investing isn't the only option, and measuring against some 'market' benchmark definitely isn't always the right choice.

I'm well aware of the ongoing bull market. It's been ups and downs it hasn't been all gains. I do believe I found a strategy that works for me. Essentially swing trading options on stocks I would buy anyway for increased leverage vs buying shares. I also have a Roth IRA where I'm just dollar cost averaging high div etfs
If you're 100% in cash, 100% SPX is probably a nonsensical benchmark.

Yeah, OP said annual but his returns are closer to YTD.  In either case it would be unusual to keep 1/3 in cash and expect to match SP500 returns -- unless you have a specific reason for doing so, like taking more risk in the stock portion of the portfolio.....
It‚Äôs still a zero-sum game and not really a proper investment.
